formattedAddress: 11 E 11th St, New York, NY 10003, USA
adrFormatAddress: 11 E 11th St, New York, NY 10003-4401, USA

originalText.text: I really love the Conservative Synagogue of Fifth Avenue. I began looking for a synagogue shortly after I moved to NYC, and after attending services at a few other synagogues, I knew this was the one for me. Everyone was very welcoming; I felt like I was home. My fiance and I enjoy Shabbat services, Friday night dinners, and other social/educational activities that they have throughout the year. This small synagogue in Greenwich Village is a hidden gem. I highly recommend checking it out!

originalText.text: Very warm place with traditional conservative services.  Many programs, shabbat dinners, etc. for a small congregation.  The new rabbi, Joe Schwartz, is a dynamic new young leader and should be great for reaching out to even a larger community.  Very cute historic building with a lovely garden out front.

text.text: Very warm place with traditional conservative services.  Many programs, shabbat dinners, etc. for a small congregation.  The new rabbi, Joe Schwartz, is a dynamic new young leader and should be great for reaching out to even a larger community.  Very cute historic building with a lovely garden out front.

originalText.text: The moment you walk into a Friday night or Saturday morning service at the Conservative Synagogue of Fifth Avenue you will feel like mishpocha (family). The first time I went to services, I went alone. I felt like everyone at the synagogue was welcoming, friendly and sincere. There are no expectations and/or pretenses about this synagogue. After attending services for a few months, I decided to become a member. My personal favorite is the once-a-month Friday night Shabbat dinner after services. It's truly a one-of-kind place and something that you owe yourself to check out.

originalText.text: wonderful place and warm congregation. It is magical. You should, of course, go to pray, but if for some reason you do not want to pray you should just go see how magical it is. The Rabbi has a beautiful voice as well.

text.text: wonderful place and warm congregation. It is magical. You should, of course, go to pray, but if for some reason you do not want to pray you should just go see how magical it is. The Rabbi has a beautiful voice as well.

originalText.text: I can’t imagine living anywhere but here in New York, and I can’t imagine living here without the warmth and support of my little shul (synagogue if you prefer) on 11th Street. It’s more than a community; it’s a family, welcoming all who pass through its patio garden. I came over 30 years ago, became an adult Bat Mitzvah, married a man who loved the shul as much as I did, and we never left. Traditional, egalitarian services, exciting Rabbis, innovative lay leadership, smart and fun congregants, great educational and social programming, and sumptuous kiddushes. Aside from the calories, what could be bad?
